chief.note: Recommissioned on October 12, 1787.

ended.note: Recall requested by the Government of France

chief.note: Morris was still at his post when his successor presented credentials.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate. Nomination was confirmed by the Senate, but no record has been found of a new commission following confirmation.

appointed.note: Commission not of record, but enclosed with an instruction of

chief.note: Received his commission about February 13, 1811; was not issued a letter of credence, but continued his official relations with the Government of France begun in September 1810 as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.

ended.note: Died at Zarnowiec, en route to Paris from consultations with French officials in Russia, on

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on May 28, 1813, after confirmation. Reaccredited when France again became a kingdom; presented new credentials on August 16, 1814.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on February 10, 1830, after confirmation. Reaccredited after change of government; formally received on January 14, 1831.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on March 5, 1834, after confirmation.
Barton closed the legation because he had been recalled.
Reaccredited on April 26, 1848, when France again became a republic.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on March 18, 1850, after confirmation. Reaccredted on January 10, 1853, when France again became an empire.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 6, 1853, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 22, 1866, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on March 2, 1867, after confirmation.
Reaccredited on May 8, 1871, when France again became a republic.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on October 30, 1877, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 23, 1937, after confirmation.

ended.note: France severed diplomatic relations with the United States on

chief.note: The Embassy in Paris had been opened to the public December 1, 1944, with Caffery in charge pending presentation of his letter of credence.

Commissioned during a recess of the Senate. Proceeded to post, but was not received by the Directory; left post on February 5, 1797. Nomination was confirmed by the Senate, but no record has been found of a new commission following confirmation.
Not commissioned; nomination superseded by a nomination of Murray and two others to serve on a joint commission.
Did not serve under this appointment.
Not commissioned; nomination rejected by the Senate.
Not commissioned; nomination rejected by the Senate.
Took oath of office, but did not proceed to post in this capacity.
